column11: Review Text

column8: Impressive ruins of an ancient palace destroyed during war.
column11: A seven storied wooded palace of ancient Sri Lankan kings destroyed by enemy during war. It is believed that the seven story palace of King Parakrambahu was set on fire by the armies of Chola dynasties about a thousand years ago. The thick walls with holes placed at regular intervals were used as reinforcements for he wooden beams which were supporting the seven storied palace. A well preserved staircase leading to no where is what is left of the upper floors. The high finish of the rooms can be visualized by highly polished wall plaster which is still visible. A must visit while you are in Polonnaruwa, Sri Lanka. Recommended.

column8: Standing in the Footsteps of Royalty
column11: Visiting the Royal Palace of King Maha Parakramabahu was one of my favorite experiences in Polonnaruwa. Even though only the walls and foundations remain, you can feel how grand and powerful this place once was. The palace grounds are huge. The brick walls are thick and rise several meters high, and you can still see doorways, corridors, and the layout of rooms. It’s incredible to imagine that this place once had over 1,000 rooms! I found it fascinating how the palace was built with so much detail, despite being from the 12th century. The stone steps are beautifully crafted, and you’ll notice small carvings and architectural details if you look closely. The ticket counter is right near the palace, so it’s easy to start your exploration here. The staff were friendly and helpful in explaining where to go next. There’s plenty of shade from trees around the ruins, which makes walking around comfortable even on a hot day. And there’s a sense of peace — as if time has slowed down. If you love history, ancient architecture, and imagining life in a royal court, you absolutely shouldn’t miss this place. Tip: Bring water, wear comfortable shoes, and take your time exploring every corner. The details are what make it so special!

This is near the ticket office and museum.  We had a car drive us as a half day trip from Sigiriya and were glad for the AC.  It was very hot.  The museum gives quite a bit of detail of how these ruins looked like and their purpose which was interesting. You do need to remove your shoes and hats at some places, take socks as the ground is so hot and your feet get burnt.

Near the ticket office is the Royal Palace, a brick building, very impressive although not well preserved. The Royal Palace dates back to the dynasty of King Parakramabahu I (1153 – 1186). It is said that the palace contained 50 rooms spread over 7 floors. probably the upper parts were made of wood, lighter than the masonry.

I'm talking about the whole temple and shrine complex in Polonaruwa. If you like history and culture, this is your place. At first you must buy the tickets in the museum, then you can explore the whole town. Be prepared to remove your shoes from time to time.

My Favorite place in Polonnaruwa. This was a old Palace and it was Seven stairs building. First three stairs builded using bricks and next four builded using wood. Now days only available for see the first floor.and the part of the staircase still available. And I’ve seen the old attached toilet system in here.Very surprising. Some of old original wall plasters still available and protected. According to the guide who explained about this palace. It was burned by enemy army. Some of burned marks and lava stones still available. Very wonderful place. I love and definitely visit this place again.

The palace of King Parakramabahu, the Great. It is believed that the palace was 7 storeys high during its peak and glorious time, which housed 1,000 chambers. What is left is the 3 storeys high concrete of ruins. Still, it is majestic looking and it makes your imaginations run wild to think of how magnificent this palace was during the glorious days. One of the must-see site at Polonnaruwa Heritage site.
Interesting the sizes and shapes of these ruins, but other than that, not much to see. A lack of information or signage didn’t help.

The palace was built by Parakramabahu I. It purportedly had seven floors and one thousand rooms, the former more credible to historians than the latter. The remains of three levels does give a glimpse of what would have been a monumental structure.
Carvings, religion, human skill, natural beauty of stone - the lure of ancient mystery! Can spend hours in these places...
This is the ruins of a 7 story building from a former kingdom from thousands of years ago.  It's part of the historical polonnaruwa ruins and definitely worth a visit.

This is just one part of a very large complex.  It's nice to imagine how it might have looked when it was not in ruins.  Take your time to stroll around, and watch out for the monkeys who might try to grab your food or drink.

We started our explorations of Polonnaruwa at the Weijantha Prasada and while its history is of interest, there are much more fascinating sites within Polonnaruwa. The ruins themselves are large, but its hard to picture what this once looked like. It was incredibly busy with tour groups when we visited. If you are tight on time, you can give this one a miss.

The ruins of this once grand palace that measured 7 storeys and had about 1000 rooms is impressive if you allow your mind to imagine what it originally looked like. Now only a small part of the palace, the walled gardens and queen's pool remain.
The entrance was beautiful but inside nothing special just old walls . But as you get tickets for all ancient places it is good to visit this one also.
Once a towering 7 storey Palace, what now remains gives an idea of it’s former glory & importance. To see a replica of how it would have looked in its heyday, visit the Nearby Archaeological Museum.

This is what remains of the kings Palace. Records say this stood five story's and had around 1000 rooms ?? Only occupied for a very short period. This is part of the second oldest kingdom in Sri Lanka.
This is one of the more interesting ruins you will see on your way around the ruins. This is the king's palace.
Not the most informative in terms of explanation.  Unless you do some research beforehand, it is hard to envision the grandeur of the palace.
this was a 7 storey building once. It would have been very impressive. Let your imagination work and  it is still just that.
Weijantha Prasada is a part of Polonnaruwa and it represents ruins of the Royal Palace. Impressive building such a big palace in those days without machines!
This palace was once 7 stories, but the current ruins are far smaller. Take a wander, it still feels quite grand. Well, at the area where the tallest walls still stand.

Not much is left - just the stairway and part of the walls of what was once (about 12th century AD) the palace of King Vijayabahu  in the capital of the second oldest kingdom of the island, the Kingdom of Plonaruwa. Apparently the building was seven stories tall back then, but now you can only see three stories high wall ruins... Small remains of the ancient glory...

What remains of the Royal Palace are ruins of thick brick walls. This is one of the first landmark, the visitor gets to see when going through Archaeological sites. The Palace is believed to be built in the 12th Century. The present structure does not appear grand and does not give any indications of its past magnificence.However, what remains does gives an appearance that the original structure must have been a huge one.
what you can see here is the foundation of what used to be a 7 store house , wooden built from hundreds of years ago ... wow
Though there are only few walls are remaining of a once gigantic palace, you do get a feeling of its grandiose once you actually visit the place.

This is the palace of the greatest king who lived in polonnaruwa. please refer to the structure available at the Museum before visit in this place. Has been built on Brick Foundation and wooden structure on top of that. they had been 7 stories in this palace and more than 2000 rooms.
This Palace originally had seven stories and even though only three remain it is possible to envisage what a fabulous construction this must have been. Still impressive even in this ruined state.

This was one of the first sites we visited in Polonnaruwa, the remains of the royal Palace. It once stood seven stories high but only three remain today as the upper floors were burned down. It would be a shame if you visited Polonnaruwa and left out the palace surely?! It's a great introduction to the area and the wonders it holds. You can see all the little tiny rooms where the kings servants worked and stayed and there are still some beautiful carvings left that survived the fire. We'll worth a visit but a guide is vital as you just won't get the same level of knowledge of the place from books or display boards.

The whole temple complex is more just ruins and two or three temples. Rent a bike and ride trough. But the acces is quite expensive (25 usd) and it is just a ruins. We were 4 girls and some indian guy was waiting for us behind the temple with his penis out jerking off. Not pleasant experience. We tried to tell it to the officer in the park but he didnt understand us. But we saw monkeys, turtle and some kind of deer. Like on a saffari :)

We visited this site in June as part of a group tour through Trip A Deal. Our guide, Lakmal, lead us through the site explaining all the history and the site and the importance of it today. Like many other sites in Sri lanka, this was so interesting. You really need a guide to explain everything to you. Without one, we would have missed so much. Well worth the visit.
Located in polonnaruwa visit site. It was the palace of king parakaramabahu. Now available only bricķ walls here.

This is the remains of "Parakramabahu's" original palace which once stood 7 stories high but now is about 3stories tall and is in ruins. Originally it was a massive building complex but it is now difficult to see  outlines. The standing walls have large holes in them that supported floor beams (which must have been massive).
This was the seven floor palace that was burnt down by the rebels. The model of the palace can be seen at the museum.

When you go to the museum, you will see a model of how this place looked originally, when it was 7 stories tall and the top 5 were made of wood.  Just shows you the amazing architecture that was all over Polonnaruwa. One of the better sites here.

The palace itself, in current form, is nothing but a two story ruin. However, you have to understand the past and imagine (or see in the museum)  the magnificence of the place when it was in its full glory. So, make sure to go to the museum first, see the replica of the original palace and then come to visit this site in order to understand the importance of this site.

Once you het there you realise that it is a lot smaller than pictured. Also in the museam we saw models of what wxperts think it looked like, but they did not make a lot of sence once there. It is OK to visit since it is very close to other sites, but do not expect to be wow

There are a dozen pieces in this museum that are world class masterpieces such as the sitting bodhisattva, but too many standouts to mention.  Quiet, serene and elegant presentation with much info to digest and casts a light on the history of the area.

A visit through Polonnaruwa ruins would not be complete without visiting Weijantha Prasada.  This being the Palace of the King, it is amazing to stand amongst the ruins (especially having seen what it would have been like in its day at the Archaeological Museum) and just take it the grandeur and impressive construction and ornate works. Everyone should be respectful for the dress code they don’t offer sarongs so best to take one yourself, and remove your hat.  Would visit again and recommend to others.

To be correctly said Waijayanthi Prasadaya in Sinhala... Palace of great king Parakramabahu I.... remain only the structure of which was a 7 story building according to the history. Some people genuinely said that nothing of worth in here but you may not come across such a huge palace structure belong to Anuradhapura- Polonnaruwa era other than this place... at least it has brick walls still intact..... So if you know the history, then you’ll understand the value of this magnificent place...
There is nothing left except the place this was standing.You can give it a miss or just walk past if you have time.

Must visit the ruins of the palace of the kings. This is a multi-storeyed structure that is of course now in ruins. But looking at it you know it must have been beautiful and imposing in its time. Adds to the overall beauty of the ruins in Polonnaruwa.
All that is left of this ancient palace are a few brick walls. No statues no engravings no roof no inscriptions. Simple pleasant and nice. Takes a few minutes to walk round and that's It!

If you are visiting Polonnaruwa ancient city (which is the second kingdom in Sri Lanka) , Weijantha Prasada is a hard place to miss. It was the Royal Palace back in the days which is believed to be seven stories high. Simply it was an ancient sky scraper. Now we can only see about three stories of this ancient palace. It is believed that the palace consisted 1000 rooms.
The pillared structure near the Nissanka Lata Mandapa is considered to be the area where the kings council members must have met. A part of the Sacred Quardrangle.
This is a huge area, literally a palace. Among all the relics of Polonnaruwa old city, We liked this place most. So, recommending this.
Large ruins of a royal palace, at this moment only some walls rest as well as some parts of old plaster.
Begin your visit by the ancient palace of Polonnaruwa, the Citadel. Then, go ahead to the last ruin on the top (2km up the hill, Thivanka Image house) and come back down slowly... by bike!!

This World Heritage site is well worth a visit but unless it's really your thing you might just want to do some editing. The remains are well preserved and well presented in their settings. You need to travel around the site a bit so some wheels - even if it's the eponymous tuk tuk are worth having.

the Weijantha Prasada was the royal palace during the height of the 11th to 13th centuries golden era in Sri Lanka. Not so much left of it now, but enough to give a sense of the grandeur that it must have been.  Near the entrance to the archaeological park.  Worth a quick look.
This is part of Polonnaruwa archaeological part and not the most interesting part of it.   Expensive to enter 3,750 lkr and you need transport to get around the park.

This majestic palace with the ruins rising several storeys above the ground. and over 2 m thick walls. Badly damaged in parts but enough to realise the importance of the building. Behind the entrance many ruins of several rooms showing good insight of the palaces importance
This is another of the major ruins in the main archeological park and hard to be missed if one follows the logical tour trough the park.
Ancient palace that are badly ruined.   But, you still can see the base of the rooms, toilet, and the king's meeting room.

The place has been kept as much as they can as weather can ruin this place, but what's left of it is still an amazing place to visit when you are in this are. Ruins are just simply amazing to me as I imagined what it would be like back in history, people living in that year and their culture as well.

Thought there would be more than a few wall with holes where beams would have been...lots of rooms shown with foundations only but no real descriptions of what they could be used for...rooms we were told they  think were for wives were v small so felt sorry for them...
No words to describe this !!! Rare place as these much of royal palace is preserved now also and its still staying in this environment !!!
The columns are imposing but that's it! Nothing much left of this 7-storied palace. You can go in and out in 15mins. The most interesting bit for me is the stairway to nowhere. Ghastly!

A short flight of steps leads you to the two story remains of what was once supposed to be seven stories. If so the upper stories would have been made of wood. Although there is not much left of the building, what is gives a good indication of the massive size it would once have been
This structure is on the right hand side after you enter the enclosed area of the ruins. You could make a quick stop to see it, or skip it if you're short of time.
Impressive and large complex. It is amazing to think of its grandeur when it was first built as supposedly it was seven stories tall.
This is 1600 years old and you get a feel for how big this palace was. See the model first in the museum then go experience it
This is probably the most impressive structure on the site and despite its age the walls are still pretty much intact.  Get a local guide to assist with the history or use a good guide book.
This used to be seven stories high....this is all that remains of the kings palace. all interesting sites are close to each other...i mean the other ruins.

On walking through the main entrance you get a real sense of how extensive the grounds of the site were. The foundations of many buildings can be seen from this location. When we visited there was a large band of monkeys on the entrance walls, they were an attractions in their own right .... Very cheeky and fun to watch them scampering about.

Although the thick remaining walls of the once Royal Palace are impressive, and make a great photographic opportunity, there is very little to see. However, worth strolling to the nearby Audience Hall and Bathing Pool.

This is the stone/brick base of a rulers 'castle' which was about 7 storeys high and topped with wooden structures above what remains of the stone/brick base. This is a great historical site and one at which you can get ample information to give you the background to the ruins. If you like history you should go, if you don't like history you should still go just in case this is what spurs you to become interested in the rise and fall of civilisations.
Part of hte royal palace group - purportedly the palaces great hall this site isn't as heavily populated by tourists and somewhat easier to navigate.

One of the best things about ambling through the ancient ruins in Polonnaruwa is being able to use your mind's eye to imagine and visualise what this city must have looked like in all its glory. This palace is supposed to have had 7 floors and today very little remains of it. However, it is easy to see how gorgeous it would have looked in its times based on the symmetry, the positioning of various corridors and pillars.
Use you imagination and try to visualise this Palace when it consisted of seven floors, what an engineering masterpiece.
Its a nice place of Old architecture. This is one of the mail buildings of a whole ancient city and a whole ancient civilisation.

This palace is said to have 7 floors we still can see 4 of them. It's a wonder of stone masonry of the time. The walls are few feet thick and you can see the hole through which support beams of upper floors were run. The plaque in front will describe and will show you a plan of it as it was during the king's time.

i think this is a sight you shall not stop at all while visiting the sights, it give you general idea about whole city and you can walk inside the ruins and start to imagine :) i recommend this for sure, it doesn't take you too much time
This truly is a wonderful place, a defeneitely must see. This is one of the mail buildings of a whole ancient city and a whole ancient civilisation. People who have not been to

My spouse and I had a short visit because of heavy rain. We were impressed with these soaring 30-foot  massive walls, which are the remains of a once majestic palace of the king. Had the weather been better, we would have liked to walk around and explore it in more detail.

It was rainy the day I visited Polonnaruwa, but when I saw this building and walked around in it, I was just amazed at the design and structure of it.  The second king of the city built this palace as well as the parliament building that is a short walk away, but the color of this building and its design are very unique and it was neat to see not just the ground floor walls but those of the first floor are still there as well...
It is belived to be the lpalace of teh king and signes are that it was a maltiple soried building, ruines around it support the belif that it is a recedance of some kind.
These are the remains of the huge royal palace and gardens. The remains of the palace behind the main entrance are a very nice spot to stroll around.

This magnificent structure built by King Parakramabahu I, the great Polonnaruwa monarch  is said to have consisted of seven stories and 1000 chambers. The building has been set on fire by Chola invaders. Only the massive walls which are about 9 metres in height and the bottom half of the main staircase which led to the upper floors remain at present. You can also see the remains of buildings where the ministers, guards and other aides lived.

The remains of what was a royal palace are well worth a visit while at Polonnaruwa. The scale of what remains of the ruins are impressive enough let alone to think what it would have looked like in times past.
This is the remains of the Royal Palace after the war. Nice place to capture some photographs compared to other places in this area.

The palace of King Parakramabahu the Great was supposed to have comprised of 7 storeys. The best time to visit is early morning when the morning sun light hits the building. It gives an amazing yellow/ orange glow.
